title: The Effects of Professionals' Human and Cultural Capital for Interprofessional Social Capital: Exploring Professional Identities, Knowledges and Learn
abstractText:
This seminar series aims to:

  • bring together social scientists and practitioners from children’s public sector services together with policy makers and users, practitioners in local authorities, and postgraduate students;
  • exchange conceptual, theoretical, empirical and analytical insights;
  • explore a number of important and timely questions relating to shifting professional identities, knowledge bases and inter/professional relations arising from children’s services transformations. 

Seminar themes include questioning professional identities, examining models and typifications of professional knowledge and exploring their applicability to changing inter/professional practices, social capital and power relations in schools.

The objectives (methods) are to:

  • examine the tensions and complementarities in the disciplinary theory and professional practices found across children’s services;
  • investigate the implications and challenges for practitioners and professional groups across child/youth sector practice networks and teams with particular reference to how children’s services integration policy and workforce remodelling is operating;
  • examine the wider socio-economic debates on the social capital-human capital relation and in particular explore how professionals’ human capital may produce inter/professional social capital;
  • provide a practitioners’ forum on ‘joined-up working’ across the child/youth sector; 
  • identify opportunities for building collaborative research networks and openings for theoretical scholarship and empirical research.
